explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — This macro (or inline helper) is the most likely place to contain compiler extensions (e.g. GNU statement-expressions ({...}), typeof, __attribute__, or other non-standard constructs). You must inspect its definition to determine if a language extension is used.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — The static call graph indicates the macro/implementation may expand to or call this symbol. Its implementation could use extensions (inline functions with attributes, typeof, or non-standard constructs), so include it.

OS_impl_count_sem_table — The object/table referenced by the macro could be defined with compiler-specific extensions (section attributes, aligned/packed attributes, or special qualifiers). Its definition is needed to check for such extensions and to understand the macro expansion result type.

OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t — The type of impl (structure) must be inspected for any compiler extensions in its definition (e.g. bit-field types, anonymous structs/unions, attributes, packed/aligned pragmas) and to verify that taking &impl->id is standard.

OS_object_token_t — The token type (and any associated typedefs/macros) must be checked for use of extensions (pointer-to-GNU-extension types, anonymous/unusual typedef constructs) and to confirm that the expression *token is standard.

sem_wait — The external function called; include its declaration to confirm it is a standard POSIX API and not a macro that expands to compiler-specific code (or to detect any nonstandard attributes on its declaration).

sem_t — The semaphore type used by impl->id must be inspected for nonstandard/compiler-specific declarations or typedefs that could constitute a language extension.

OS_SEM_FAILURE, OS_SUCCESS — The symbolic return macros/constants must be inspected to ensure they are standard integer constants/macros and do not hide compiler extensions (e.g. complex macros or extension attributes).

Together these symbols cover the macro expansion, the types and objects accessed, and the external function call; inspecting their definitions will reveal any use of compiler-specific language extensions relevant to the MISRA rule.
